18.text:
Jon Alger: Good afternoon. I'm Jon Alger,
president here at James Madison University

21.text:
and I want to welcome you to the Forbes Center
Concert Hall. Today we continue our new tradition

27.text:
in this space, the Madison Vision Series.
This series has been developed to advance

34.text:
the university's efforts to prepare students
to be educated and enlightened citizens who

39.text:
lead productive and meaningful lives by looking
at contemporary issues in an engaged society.

47.text:
This series will bring prominent speakers
to campus to look at our current civic landscape

51.text:
through the prism of creating an engaged and
enlightened citizenry. Later this academic

58.text:
year we'll be privileged to be joined by
Cynthia Cooper, the World-Com whistle blower

63.text:
on November 13th, Jeffrey Rosen, the chief
executive officer of the National Constitution

68.text:
Center in Philadelphia, who will be with us
during Madison Week in March and our own Carly

74.text:
Fiorina who, of course, is a member of the
current JMU Board of Visitors and she'll

78.text:
be with us in April. Some of you may be familiar
with the Madison quote in the tunnel connecting

85.text:
the Forbes Center to the Quad: "Knowledge
will forever govern ignorance." Or the quote

91.text:
at the top of your program: "The advancement
and diffusion of knowledge is the only guardian

97.text:
of true liberty." Those quotes capture not
just the purpose of this series but also the

104.text:
purpose of higher education and in particular
the liberal arts and sciences education that

110.text:
we strive to offer here at James Madison University.
As the institution named for James Madison,

118.text:
we have a special responsibility to foster
this dialogue. We believe that this education

125.text:
meets the demands of the 21st Century: demands
for more college educated workers who will

131.text:
be engaged citizens and lifelong learners.
So how do we ensure that our students are

137.text:
prepared for a rapidly changing landscape
in terms of technology and innovation, and

143.text:
globalization? What skills will they need
to succeed and thrive over the course of their

148.text:
careers and their lives? How do we produce
graduates who will contribute to our civic

155.text:
good? Now, this last question might be particular
important as we watch events in Washington

160.text:
unfolding. So, today's speaker is one of
the nation's leading voices on these important

169.text:
topics. Dr. Carol Geary Schneider is president
of the Association of American Colleges and

176.text:
Universities, or AAC&U for short, with nearly
1300 member institutions drawn from all aspects

183.text:
of higher education, AAC&U is the leading
national organization devoted to advancing

189.text:
and strengthening undergraduate liberal education.
Under Dr. Schneider's leadership, AAC&U

196.text:
launched Liberal Education and America's
Promise, or LEAP, a public advocacy and campus

204.text:
action initiative designed to engage students
and the public with what really matters in

210.text:
a college education for the 21st Century.
The LEAP campaign builds in turn on AAC&U's

218.text:
major effort, with which some of you may be
familiar, called Greater Expectations, the

223.text:
Commitment to Quality as a Nation Goes to
College, which was an initiative designed

228.text:
to articulate the aims of a 21st Century liberal
education and to identify comprehensive, innovative

234.text:
models that improve learning for all undergraduate
students. AAC&U has studied and advocated

241.text:
for high impact learning practices and has
engaged institutions and employers across

247.text:
the country in a national conversation on
these big picture issues. Carol and the AAC&U

254.text:
have also been champions for extending the
benefits of liberal arts and sciences education

259.text:
to students of all backgrounds, including
those who have been historically under-served

265.text:
and to infusing these values across the entire
curriculum. Dr. Schneider has a bachelor's

271.text:
degree in history from Mount Holyoke College
and a Ph.D. in history from Harvard. She's

277.text:
taught at the University of Chicago, DePaul,
Chicago State and Boston University and has

283.text:
published extensively. Dr. Schneider has received
eleven honorary degrees and a number of national

290.text:
awards in higher education. For example, in
2013 she was honored as one of Diverse Magazine's

297.text:
25 Leading Women in Higher Education. Finally
on a personal note, let me add that I have

304.text:
known Carol for many years and I consider
her to be one of the great thinkers and leaders

311.text:
in higher education. So, it is my distinct
honor to welcome to the Forbes Center stage

319.text:
Carol Geary Schneider: Well, thank you so
much for that very kind introduction, for

341.text:
the opportunity to be with you, and not least
for the opportunity to be away, however briefly,

347.text:
from Washington DC. I am mindful, always of
the notion, the humility that must accompany

355.text:
the good news that I have come here from Washington
to give you advice. So let me hasten to say

363.text:
that it's a special privilege and honor
to come to James Madison University because

367.text:
you have been partners with us for the entire
length of my presidency at AAC&U and a good

374.text:
many of the things that I'm going to be
talking about tonight, you have been pioneering

378.text:
at JMU and the discussion tonight, I think,
is about how we take the extremely strong

385.text:
foundations that you've already laid and
carry them to another level for your students,

390.text:
and as Jonathan has so wonderfully said, and
a vision for engaged and civically responsible

396.text:
liberal education that can in fact service
our society and our democracy. So, that's

403.text:
my topic for tonight. How do we think about
liberal education, engaged learning, student

408.text:
success, how do we think about these things
in the context of a renewed commitment to

412.text:
preparing students for leadership in a society
that takes its own democratic heritage seriously?

420.text:
And moves ethical questions to the center?
And how do we do this in ways that build on

425.text:
the extraordinary work that you have already
done here in creating a highly engaged and

430.text:
increasingly influential model for undergraduate
education? So, you should have found as you

436.text:
came in a handout, at many points I'm going
to be referring to it, so it would be helpful

442.text:
to you to have it in your hands so that we
can look at its topics together. Jonathan

449.text:
mentioned LEAP, the work that I'm describing
is central to what AAC&U calls its LEAP campaign.

455.text:
I am not going to describe that campaign,
but I have given you, on page two of your

460.text:
handout, an overview of what's involved,
who takes part, what we're actually doing

465.text:
and you can review that for yourself. In my
remarks, I'm going to be talking about the

471.text:
terms of our discussion. What do we actually
mean by liberal education and how does it

475.text:
support meaningful student success? What does
it mean within that broader context to refocus

481.text:
on civic and ethical purposes of liberal education
and to make them actually pervasive across

487.text:
the education experience? What practices can
get us there? What is the role of high impact

493.text:
practices in developing a national model for
an engaged and civic minded and ethical university?

498.text:
And what does all of this mean for James Madison
and your own inspiring determination to, as

505.text:
you have said to yourself and your students,
Be The Change? So, that's the overview of

511.text:
the whole talk and let's turn now to what
it really means to clarify our terms. How

518.text:
many of you are in fact students? Hands up.
And how many of you arrived at JMU with a

524.text:
really solid understanding of what it meant
to get a liberal education? Any hands up?

531.text:
[laughs] And that's the insight, really,
that stands behind our LEAP initiative, that,

537.text:
in fact, we need to clarify our terms in order
to help people understand what it is that

544.text:
a liberal education provides at its best and
why it matters so much to students' long

548.text:
term success in many fronts, we really need
to begin to clarify the language. So liberal

554.text:
education isn't, in fact, the most commonly
used term for much of what I'm about to

558.text:
describe, but AAC&U has very deliberately
gone back to the 19th Century and the 18th

563.text:
Century, to Thomas Jefferson's and James
Madison's term for describing the kind of

567.text:
education that would secure a free society.
And I'm going to be distinguishing in these

573.text:
remarks among liberal education on the one
hand, general education, in which you are

578.text:
a national leader on the second hand, the
liberal arts and sciences which are foundational

583.text:
to general education and also to liberal education,
but the main point of this whole approach

589.text:
to liberal education is to argue that what
we're talking about doesn't belong just

594.text:
to general education, isn't limited to the
arts and sciences only although they are important

599.text:
to it but that our real focus is on liberal
education across the curriculum, all students,

605.text:
all majors, all parts of the educational experience,
formal, informal, curricular, co-curricular.

612.text:
So that's the general idea and you'll
see a guide to commonly confused terms that

617.text:
you might like to take away, on page three
of the handout and a more elaborate definition

623.text:
of liberal education that I will be articulating
in these remarks going forward. But in brief,

630.text:
what is it we're talking about when we talk
about providing students with a liberal education?

635.text:
I want to argue that there are three enduring
goals, certainly since the founding of colleges

642.text:
and universities starting with the 18th Century
in our own society, but if you go back over

647.text:
the millennia, if you go back to what Cicero
is talking about when he talks about education,

651.text:
there are three enduring goals that remain
important, remain primary to what we mean

657.text:
by liberal education. The first is that a
liberal and liberating education provides

664.text:
students with broad knowledge of their own
world, the world around them. Of science,

668.text:
of history, of society, of cultures, it's
the knowledge you need for successful leadership

674.text:
in a world in which you have standing. And
of course, for a very long time that kind

678.text:
of knowledge was restricted only to a tiny
fraction of the population. But the opportunity

682.text:
we have today is that this kind of leadership
knowledge becomes democratic, civic knowledge,

687.text:
knowledge that matters to everyone. So broad
knowledge is foundational to it. The second

692.text:
is a focus on the powers of the mind because
ultimately that is all we have to solve the

697.text:
many problems we face in own lives and work
and in society. So the way in which we've

703.text:
thought about developing powers of the mind,
reasoning, discernment, judgment, has evolved

708.text:
over time. It was certainly approached differently
in the 12th Century or the 16th Century or

712.text:
the 18th Century from what we are doing now,
but the focus on taking your intellectual

717.text:
capacities to their highest level of development
and making them permanent resources is crucial

723.text:
to the notion of liberal education. And the
third, again you can track it back to the

729.text:
ancient world and it remains central today
for all of us, is a notion of cultivating

734.text:
personal integrity. Graduating students who
see it as their role to take responsibility

739.text:
for the ethical challenges they will face
in life and who see it as part of their role

743.text:
to contribute to the greater good. So, enduring
goals, but also evolving practices. Liberal

750.text:
education is our premiere tradition in American
higher education. It's what you get in every

756.text:
honor's program in the country. It's what
you get at all the most selective colleges

761.text:
in the country, including institutions like
MIT which are much better known for their

765.text:
work in STEM; they provide a liberal education
to their students and it's what you get

770.text:
here at James Madison University. A liberal
education that prepares you with all those

776.text:
forms of learning that I just described but
equally important, the reason liberal education

782.text:
has remained our premiere tradition is because
it never stands firm. It is always connecting

788.text:
what it does with the needs of the world around
it and it is always rethinking its practices

793.text:
as you are doing, to ensure that students
are optimally prepared for the challenges

797.text:
of the particular time and place that they
find themselves in. Now for the founders,

803.text:
it was profoundly clear that we needed liberal
education, solid in the liberal arts and sciences

809.text:
to ensure the future of freedom. That there
was a close and necessary connection between

814.text:
cultivating civic virtue and ensuring the
future of a free society. The governors in

821.text:
our society are you, the citizens, not the
people who are behaving so badly at the moment

826.text:
in our Congress. We sent them there but we
also can recall them. They are finally obliged

832.text:
to us. But that raises the standing of our
role in providing leadership for a society

838.text:
that makes changes, decisions and choices
that influences not just our own communities

844.text:
but for the United States influences the rest
of the world as well. So, all of this was

849.text:
crystal clear to our founders. It was crystal
clear throughout the 19th Century. It was

855.text:
crystal clear as late as the post-World War
II era and I'll come back to that in a couple

861.text:
of minutes, but I think we would all agree
that today American society has largely lost

866.text:
sight of the civic and ethical purposes of
liberal education. We don't hear those talked

871.text:
about and we need to. It's in that context
that AAC&U decided to spend at least a decade,

877.text:
and now we know it will be more than that,
with what we call our LEAP initiative. We

881.text:
are working to reclaim a broader understanding
of what matters in a 21st Century education

887.text:
and to drive those purposes and commitments
centrally into all parts of the educational

892.text:
experience. I've got two ways of representing
this, one is on page four of your handout

899.text:
and we actually captured there the 20th Century
understanding of liberal education and contrast

905.text:
it with where we're going today. So if you
look at page four and look at the right hand

909.text:
column, what we're arguing is that this
is a necessity for all students, it's essential

914.text:
for success in a global economy, also for
informed citizenship, at home and abroad,

920.text:
that it provides intellectual, civic, personal
and professional development together and

924.text:
that this is achieved by studies that emphasize
a set of essential learning outcomes across

929.text:
the entire educational experience, all fields
of study, general education working together.

935.text:
So the vision is one of all schools, whether
we're talking about community colleges and

941.text:
technical programs or the purest liberal arts
only institutions, we really are talking about

947.text:
an education that invests in the future of
democracy and the future of individual success

953.text:
for all our students across the entire educational
experience. The heart of this is what we call

959.text:
the LEAP essential goals for liberal education,
essential learning outcomes. They're captured

967.text:
in the PowerPoint briefly and in more detail
on page five of your handout, and they should

973.text:
be familiar to you because these are, as I
said, we developed this vision in partnership

977.text:
with you and thoughtful institutions like
you and we belivee they capture the kind of

983.text:
learning you are trying to provide to your
students. As you see the LEAP essential learning

988.text:
outcomes build on those enduring goals of
liberal education that I described before

993.text:
but they carry those goals into a 21st Century
context with 21st Century particulars. So

999.text:
we still want students to have broad knowledge
of human cultures and the nature and physical

1004.text:
world achieved through studies in the arts
and sciences, but there's the argument in

1008.text:
LEAP is that these studies need to be focused
by students' engagement with big questions,

1014.text:
significant questions, questions that may
be enduring over time or important to our

1018.text:
time, but questions whose importance the students
themselves can see. A set of intellectual

1024.text:
and practical skills that are foundational
to your general education program and to liberal

1029.text:
education at JMU, the argument is that these
need to be practiced extensively from before

1035.text:
you ever get to college and taken to a higher
level, so that they are in fact part of students'

1039.text:
portfolio when they graduate from this institution.
We've also lifted up in this vision the

1045.text:
notion that we are educating students for
a citizenship. We've called this education

1049.text:
for personal and social responsibility and
the particulars are exactly what you are talking

1054.text:
about here as you go through your strategic
plan and put together your direction for the

1059.text:
future. We want students who have civic knowledge
and engagement at home and abroad, intercultural

1064.text:
learning and competence, ethical reasoning
in action and the foundations for continued,

1070.text:
life-long learning. But we also want to make
sure that students have anchored that sense

1075.text:
of civic and personal responsibility in direct
work with and learning from communities beyond

1082.text:
the academy. That it's not enough to talk
about civic virtue here; we really need to

1086.text:
be engaged with the world around us and I
know that this is an area in which JMU is

1091.text:
already a leader. But the thing that I would
argue makes this a 21st Century vision and

1097.text:
differentiates it from earlier conceptions
of liberal education is the emphasis on integrating

1102.text:
and applying learning. It's not enough to
know; it's not enough to have the skills;

1107.text:
it's not even enough to have a sense of
civic and ethical obligation, what really

1111.text:
matters is whether our graduates can integrate
all that and apply it to problems that matter

1116.text:
to them, that matter to our society, that
matter in the workplace. What can they do

1121.text:
with their learning? That is the core question,
we would argue, we all need to be asking ourselves

1126.text:
as we work to make the most, the most of this
important tradition for our students. Now,

1133.text:
cued by the discussion I know you're having
here in the context of your strategic plan

1138.text:
and inspired, frankly, by the mission that
you have has an institution, I have focused

1143.text:
this talk primarily on civic and ethical engagement,
but we are in a moment in time when everyone

1150.text:
wants to know, okay, how does this work for
jobs? What do employers think about this?

1155.text:
Is this too theoretical, is it too idealistic,
is it practical enough to help our students

1160.text:
make their way in a very challenging economic
environment? And AAC&U has taken that exact

1167.text:
question very seriously in the course of our
LEAP campaign. Before we launched it we brought

1173.text:
employers to the table; we listened to them;
we noticed that they didn't use the vocabulary

1178.text:
of liberal and liberal arts education, but
if you listened to what they actually wanted

1183.text:
from our graduates, they wanted more not less
of what I've been talking about. We have

1188.text:
also commissioned a set of surveys of employers,
there are four of them all together, and I've

1193.text:
brought you some information which you'll
find on page six from the latest survey. It's

1199.text:
called It Takes More Than a Major and what
it shows is that employers strongly value

1205.text:
the hallmark LEAP goals for success, the hallmark
goals for liberal learning and see them as

1211.text:
essential to success in the workplace. They
also value the very practices that help to

1216.text:
build civic and ethical problem solving capacities.
So you'll find that on page six and you'll

1223.text:
see, the questions that were given to employers
took two forms. One was, here's a set of

1228.text:
outcomes that many institutions are working
on, which do you think require less, the same

1235.text:
or more attention? So, if it has a little
diamond by it the employers said we want more

1241.text:
attention to these outcomes, and you will
see that they want more attention to many

1246.text:
of the intellectual skills and they want more
attention to ethical decision making as well.

1253.text:
The second question had to do with whatever
a student's major, do you strongly agree,

1259.text:
somewhat agree, not agree, strongly disagree
that all students need the following. So the

1264.text:
questions about broad knowledge in the liberal
arts and sciences, or broad global knowledge

1268.text:
or direct experience with community problem
solving, those all came from questions that

1274.text:
took that form that I've just described.
Now for the work that you are doing, thinking

1281.text:
through the Madison Collaborative, the commitment
to ethical reasoning across the curriculum,

1286.text:
ways to build on your civic history and mission,
I think it's the findings under personal

1290.text:
and social responsibility that are really
most significant for you. Ninety-one percent

1296.text:
of the employers said that they would like
students to have more experiences in problem

1302.text:
solving in diverse settings and the actual
item was more experiences solving problems

1308.text:
with people whose views are different than
their own. More experience solving problems

1314.text:
with people whose views are different than
their own. Ninety-one percent, this survey

1319.text:
was taken when we were already bound up in
knots in Washington. I think there is a longing

1323.text:
in our society for people who can negotiate
together and solve problems across difference.

1329.text:
But it's a workplace skill as well and remember
this survey was focused on success in the

1334.text:
economy. Eighty-seven percent would like to
know that students had experience in dealing

1338.text:
with ethical issues and problems important
in their own field, not just in general education

1344.text:
but something important to the student's
profession. Eight-two percent think that all

1347.text:
students should be spending time on civic
knowledge skills and judgment, contributing

1352.text:
to our society and a different question about
ethics, 64 % want more attention to ethical

1358.text:
decision making. So a very strong endorsement
from employers of exactly the kinds of things

1363.text:
that you are focusing on as an educational
community. So, understanding that this is

1374.text:
the vision for liberal education historically
and today and understanding that employers

1378.text:
will be with you as you strengthen and deepen
this already strong commitment at JMU, what

1386.text:
would it take to reclaim these civic and ethical
purposes? I've thought a lot about this

1390.text:
question. I care passionately about these
issues and it is deeply frustrating to me

1394.text:
to see a national discussion, nation policy
discussion about education that is so relentlessly

1400.text:
reductive. To have coming from our own White
House a plan to rate higher education that

1405.text:
focuses only on whether students completed,
whether or not they're employed after college,

1409.text:
whether or not they defaulted on their loans.
Our vision and our values takes in so much

1413.text:
more than that and we have a long way to go
before our society is with us on this conception

1420.text:
of education. And I've come to believe that
what is really needed is a strong, compelling

1426.text:
and widely embraced educational narrative
that focuses not just on the goals for the

1431.text:
curriculum but on why these forms of learning
are so important to democratic vitality, to

1437.text:
America's global future and to students'
long-term wellbeing as well. And we do have

1443.text:
in our recent memory exactly that kind of
a compelling educational narrative and I want

1449.text:
to share a bit of it with you as we think
about how we go forward together with this

1453.text:
vision. And that narrative was located in
the report of the Truman Commission on Higher

1459.text:
Education in 1947. Six volumes, we no longer
write six volume reports on the future of

1466.text:
higher education, we write 30 pages and we're
done, but in 1947 educators took a hard look

1475.text:
under the egis of the White House on where
higher education should go and they began

1479.text:
by identifying three, and only three, principle
purposes of higher education. And here's

1486.text:
what they are. The first is that education
should aim and achieve a fuller realization

1491.text:
of democracy in every phase of living. The
second was that education should directly

1498.text:
and explicitly build international understanding
and cooperation. And the third, and in some

1505.text:
ways my favorite, is that education should
lead to the application of creative imagination

1511.text:
and trained intelligence to the solution of
social problems. Democracy, international

1517.text:
cooperation and understanding, the solution
of social problems. Those were the primary

1522.text:
goals and the only goals that governed this
six volume vision for the future of higher

1526.text:
education. Notice the absence of any attention
to success in the workplace or jobs. We would,

1537.text:
undoubtedly a vision for the 21st Century
would need to include the economy too, but

1542.text:
imagine this big conception of what education
is for updated for our time and for our century.

1549.text:
It would change the national dialogue; it
would make it impossible to have the repeated

1553.text:
slams against the humanities and the arts
and some of the social sciences that we hear

1557.text:
from policy leaders, from governors, from
people who should know better, because it

1561.text:
is impossible to imagine that we could truly
fulfill the promise of democracy at home or

1566.text:
abroad absent the learning one gets from the
humanities and the social sciences. We couldn't

1572.text:
do it with STEM alone, important as STEM is.
You need both. You need the envisioning that

1577.text:
comes from the humanities and the arts and
the creative disciplines as well as the analytical

1583.text:
precision and the technical innovation and
creativity of the STEM and technical fields.

1590.text:
So we need this bigger vision and I would
be delighted to see leadership from it coming

1596.text:
from Virginia, a Commonwealth, founded it
at the moment in which this country committed

1604.text:
itself to democracy and liberty. This is the
place where it should begin and you have the

1608.text:
right history to do it. So, our vision might
include the fuller realization of democracy,

1616.text:
global cooperation and understanding, solutions
to the world's most urgent problems but

1622.text:
what it would also include connecting liberal
education directly with the kind of brain

1626.text:
power we need for the economy at this moment
in time when it is critically dependent on

1631.text:
innovation and creativity. I think by your
history, by your mission, by your strategic

1636.text:
direction you are well positioned to help
higher education articulate this kind of mission

1641.text:
and I hope you will see this opportunity as
a moment to take the wonderful work you have

1646.text:
already done to the next level. So, what might
it mean for JMU to take its commitment to

1652.text:
liberal education, general education, civic
and ethical responsibility to the next level?

1658.text:
I think there are two themes that are worth
your time and attention as a community. The

1664.text:
first is the notion that our students don't
need just to be prepared through attention

1669.text:
to ethical questions and civic responsibility
but they need to tie that kind of learning

1675.text:
to some of the world's myriad challenges.
And we need, secondly, to map the pathways

so that wherever students begin and wherever
